text: So what's happening is that when we have an E in the true form of the verb, like in tener, to have, like in querer, to want, when we have an E inside of the verb, that's part of the root, not part of the ending, not that er, that doesn't count, but the e in ten and the e in quer, of querer.

text: When we stress it, when we emphasise it, it often splits.

text: Most of the time, it splits into an IE under the stress of that accent.

text: Under the stress, when we say querer, we have the accent on the end, we have the accent on the ending.

text: Then when we take off that er, we put o, we would have quiero, but when we stress down that E, it splits and it becomes quiero.

text: The same for tener.
